items.title: wrong repo
Any `rendering.Image` is rendered as black by default
items.body:
Loading any image file as `rendering.Image` is rendered as black by default.
Code snippet:
```
img = rendering.Image(fname, width, height)
```
I found that setting the `rendering.Geom` color afterwards to white (`img.set_color(1., 1., 1.)`) solves this issue. It looks like the image's color is multiplied by the `rendering.Geom._color` when rendering.

It'd be nice if this was done by default in `rendering.Image.__init__()` method, it's just one additional line:

```
    def __init__(self, fname, width, height):
        Geom.__init__(self)
        self.width = width
        self.height = height
        img = pyglet.image.load(fname)
        self.img = img
        self.flip = False
  ->    self._color = (1., 1., 1., 1.)
```

items.title: pip install 'gym[all]' fails with a gcc error. mujoco_py was previously installed succesfully.
items.body:
On macOS 10.15.5, in a conda env with Python 3.7, I downloaded MuJoCo v2.0 and installed mujoco_py and was able to import it into Python and successfully run the test code [here](https://github.com/openai/mujoco-py). I have a license and mujoco_py seems to be working fine, which is why I'm filing this issue here and not in the mujoco_py repo.

When running `pip install 'gym[all]'` I get the error: `error: command '/usr/local/bin/gcc-8' failed with exit status 1`, after `Building wheel for mujoco-py (setup.py) ... error`.

Note that it initially couldn't find my default gcc/clang in /usr/bin/ and threw an error about that (even after unnecessarily adding /usr/bin/ to my PATH), but after I brew installed gcc-8 in /usr/local/bin/ that was resolved (I tried using gcc-9 first but that didn't work, so I guess it doesn't look for that).

So it successfully finds gcc-8 but for some reason it fails. You can find the full error message in [a pastebin here](https://pastebin.com/8WWEETbu).

items.title: Can't register GoalEnv and specify max_episode_steps
items.body:
Hello,

It seems that it not possible to register a `GoalEnv` and to specify `max_episode_steps` at the same time.

For example, I have this minimal environment:

```python
from gym import GoalEnv

class MyGoalEnv(GoalEnv):

    def __init__(self):
        pass
```

**This works:**
```python
from my_goal_env.envs.my_goal_env import MyGoalEnv

env = MyGoalEnv()
print(isinstance(env, gym.GoalEnv))
```
True


**This doesn't work:**

```python
from gym.envs.registration import register

register(id='test_goal_env-v0',
         entry_point='my_goal_env.envs.my_goal_env:MyGoalEnv',
         max_episode_steps=100)
```

```python
import my_goal_env

env = gym.make('test_goal_env-v0')  
print(isinstance(env, gym.GoalEnv))
```
False

I'm using gym 0.17.2.

I attached a minimal working example (run test_env.py)
[goalEnv_question.zip](https://github.com/openai/gym/files/4785322/goalEnv_question.zip)

Any idea why it is not possible to specify `max_episode_steps` for GoalEnv?

items.title: How to contribute?
items.body: I recently [added a PR](https://github.com/openai/gym/pull/1914) but the PR is just ignored so far. A [similar PR was approved](https://github.com/openai/gym/pull/1946) after discussing the issue in a ticket. If the expected way is to open a ticket for each PR, this should be noted somewhere. For me, it is unclear, which types of changes are welcome here and which are not. Now I suspect that my PR will have the same fate as many of the other open PRs on this repo. New environments are currently not added, but this is not noted somewhere. The standard on GitHub is to add a CONTRIBUTING.md to document all these things. therefore, I suggest adding such a file.

items.title: Comment mistake in classic_control/cartpole.py
items.body:
In "gym/gym/envs/classic_control/cartpole.py" I think there is a little comment mistake.

at the end of the class docstring you have this paragraph: 
```
Episode Termination:
        Pole Angle is more than 12 degrees.
        Cart Position is more than 2.4 (center of the cart reaches the edge of
        the display).
        Episode length is greater than 200.
        Solved Requirements:
        Considered solved when the average reward is greater than or equal to
        195.0 over 100 consecutive trials.
```

I think what is meant on the second to last line is "average return" instead of "average reward".

this is how it should be:
```
Episode Termination:
        Pole Angle is more than 12 degrees.
        Cart Position is more than 2.4 (center of the cart reaches the edge of
        the display).
        Episode length is greater than 200.
        Solved Requirements:
        Considered solved when the average return is greater than or equal to
        195.0 over 100 consecutive trials.
```

Very possible I could also be wrong, but this did make me confused for a few minutes.

:)

items.title: VectorEnvWrapper is broken
items.body:
The wrapper class for `VectorEnv`, introduced in #1633, does not work as expected. In contrast to the standard `Wrapper` class, it does not route function calls to the wrapped environment but relies on implementing a custom `__getattr__()` member instead. However, `VectorEnvWrapper` inherits from `VectorEnv`, and so there's no need to look up API functions like `step()` via `__getattr__` -- instead, the methods defined in the base class will be called.

The problem can be illustrated as follows:
```py
>>> import gym
>>> from gym.vector import AsyncVectorEnv
>>> from gym.vector.vector_env import VectorEnvWrapper
>>> env = VectorEnvWrapper(AsyncVectorEnv([lambda: gym.make('HalfCheetah-v2') for _ in range(3)]))
>>> env.reset()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/opt/anaconda3/envs/gym/lib/python3.7/site-packages/gym/vector/vector_env.py", line 60, in reset
    return self.reset_wait()
  File "/opt/anaconda3/envs/gym/lib/python3.7/site-packages/gym/vector/vector_env.py", line 49, in reset_wait
    raise NotImplementedError()
NotImplementedError
```

The wrapper functions that would need to be defined for `VectorEnvWrapper` to work were present in the initial version of #1633 but were then removed in favor of simply using `__getattr__()`.

`VectorEnv` introduces several new abstract functions that need to be implemented by inheriting classes, and one could argue that those should be explicitly wrapped in `VectorEnvWrapper` as well, e.g. if you'd want to just override `step_wait()`. On the other hand, these functions are intended to be "private", it might be best to remove `VectorEnvWrapper` entirely and to simply use the basic `Wrapper` class instead.

items.title: using states space as the actions space

`[0 2 1 3 3 2]
`

items.title: Does anyone know what is in the ram of atrai games?
Broken compatibility of recent release (0.15.6):  since 0.15.4
items.body:
For example, many properties of `EnvSpec` are gone since 0.15.4. This breaks many existing RL third-party softwares (e.g. SAC) and baselines.

As an example, `EnvSpec.tags` might never have been considered as a public API, but it is never documented and there was no hint of deprecation/removal: #1626 (e.g. commit https://github.com/openai/gym/commit/a99e8d153e94f532e5728b01b02b42e076334bf7). This would give an error such as `'EnvSpec' object has no attribute 'tags'`. Introduction of `FlattenDictWrapper` in favor of `FlattenObservation` (as well as so many wrapper classes) is another example. If you want to remove them, you could done an alias so people can switch to new APIs gradually.

But Why? With all due respect, I don't think this package maintains tests and semantics of versions very well. I understand backward-incompatible changes are unavoidable in many situations, but in the gym package, similar things have happened too many times. If we cannot avoid that, could you please consider bumping up versions (using better versioning schemes such as ["Semantic Versioning"]( https://semver.org/)) or at least mentioning breaking changes in the [RELEASE NOTES](https://github.com/openai/gym/blob/master/README.rst#what-s-new)? Otherwise, [specifying](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0440/#version-scheme) [version](https://github.com/openai/baselines/pull/1034) would not make much sense. 

Other references (to name only a few):

https://github.com/openai/baselines/issues/977
https://github.com/openai/baselines/issues/1051
https://github.com/openai/baselines/pull/1034
https://github.com/openai/baselines/pull/1014

Would you please pay more a careful attention to compatibility and versioning schemes, so that newer versions of gym do not break many existing codebases (which I agree and understand is definitely not easy)? Especially, given that `gym` is considered as a *de facto* standard API in the RL community. I would like to ask OpenAI developers to take this maintenance issues more seriously.

The signs of theta, theta_dt and action are not considered. If the angle < 0 and torque > 0 reward should be better than angle < 0 and torque < 0. 

So is this reward function with absolute theta, theta_d and action, ea. `(^2),` correct?

items.title: Does it matter what the shape of the observation space is (in terms of a Box object)?
items.body:
Hi, I have a very simple question regarding how the Box object should be created when defining the observable space for a rl-agent.

Assume that the observable space is a 4-dimensional state. Does it matter if I defined the observable_space in the custom environment as:

`self.observation_space = spaces.Box(low=0, high=1, shape=(2,2), dtype=np.float16)`
where I have defined it as a 2x2 matrix.
**OR**
`self.observation_space = spaces.Box(low=0, high=1, shape=(1,4), dtype=np.float16)`
where I have defined it as a 1x4 matrix (or simply, a vector).

I feel this should be quite a straightforward question; does anyone know if such minor difference in defining the space will affect the RL-algorithm which I'm passing the env into?

items.title: RGB state in FetchEnv
items.body:
I'm trying to extract rgb and depth images from multiple cameras from the FetchEnv. The default env has many cameras already defined. I tried extracting the view from the head camera with the following changes in the render function:
```
--- a/gym/envs/robotics/robot_env.py
+++ b/gym/envs/robotics/robot_env.py
@@ -5,6 +5,7 @@ import numpy as np
 import gym
 from gym import error, spaces
 from gym.utils import seeding
+import cv2
 try:
     import mujoco_py
@@ -100,6 +101,10 @@ class RobotEnv(gym.GoalEnv):
             return data[::-1, :, :]
         elif mode == 'human':
             self._get_viewer(mode).render()
+            rgb, depth = self.sim.render(width=1920, height=1080, camera_name='head_camera_rgb', depth=True)
+            cv2.imshow('rgb', cv2.cvtColor(np.flipud(rgb), cv2.COLOR_RGB2BGR))
+            cv2.imshow('depth', (np.flipud(depth) - depth.min())/(depth.max() - depth.min()))

     def _get_viewer(self, mode):
         self.viewer = self._viewers.get(mode)
```

Why is it ignoring the `camera_name` parameter?

items.title: Reset method in custom environment does not seem to be called correctly between updates
items.body:
Hello,
I am creating a custom environment to train an RL agent on. For some reason, lists in my environment are getting longer with every update, even though they are initialised to empty lists in the `reset()` method - the lists should only ever reach a maximum length of `n_steps`, the number of steps through the environment for a batch update. I believe that the reset method isn't being correctly called between updates.

Below is pseudo code for how I set up my environment

```
# customenv.py

import gym
from gym import spaces


class MyCustomEnv(gym.Env):
    def __init__(self, data):
        super().__init__()
        self.data = data  # numpy array

    def _observation(self):
        return self.data[self.current_step]  # last row of data (current step)

    def step(self):
        ...
        self.current_step += 1
        ...

    def reset(self):
        ....
        self.current_step = 0
        ...

    def render(self):
        ...
```

Then to use the custom environment

```
# main.py

import pandas as pd
from stable_baselines.common.policies import MlpLstmPolicy
from stable_baselines.common.vec_env import SubprocVecEnv
from stable_baselines import PPO2

from customenv import MyCustomEnv

# read in static data
df = pd.read_csv("my_data.csv").values  # numpy array


if __name__ == "__main__":
    train_env = DummyVecEnv([lambda: MyCustomEnv(data)])
    model = PPO2(MlpLstmPolicy, train_env, verbose=1, n_steps=1024)
    model.learn(total_timesteps=data.shape[0])
```

Do I need to manually reset the environment somewhere myself?

items.title: How to use a custom Openai gym environment with Openai stable-baselines RL algorithms?
items.body:
Hi,

I've been trying to use a custom openai gym environment for fixed wing uav from https://github.com/eivindeb/fixed-wing-gym by testing it with the openai stable-baselines algorithms but I have been running into issues for several days now. My baseline is the CartPole example Multiprocessing: Unleashing the Power of Vectorized Environments from https://stable-baselines.readthedocs.io/en/master/guide/examples.html#multiprocessing-unleashing-the-power-of-vectorized-environments since I would need to supply arguments and I am trying to use multiprocessing which I believe this example is all I need.

I have modified the baseline example as follows:

```
import gym
import numpy as np

from stable_baselines.common.policies import MlpPolicy
from stable_baselines.common.vec_env import SubprocVecEnv
from stable_baselines.common import set_global_seeds
from stable_baselines import ACKTR, PPO2
from gym_fixed_wing.fixed_wing import FixedWingAircraft


def make_env(env_id, rank, seed=0):
    """
    Utility function for multiprocessed env.

    :param env_id: (str) the environment ID
    :param num_env: (int) the number of environments you wish to have in subprocesses
    :param seed: (int) the inital seed for RNG
    :param rank: (int) index of the subprocess
    """

    def _init():
        env = FixedWingAircraft("fixed_wing_config.json")
        #env = gym.make(env_id)
        env.seed(seed + rank)
        return env

    set_global_seeds(seed)
    return _init

if __name__ == '__main__':
    env_id = "fixed_wing"
    #env_id = "CartPole-v1"
    num_cpu = 4  # Number of processes to use
    # Create the vectorized environment
    env = SubprocVecEnv([lambda: FixedWingAircraft for i in range(num_cpu)])
    #env = SubprocVecEnv([make_env(env_id, i) for i in range(num_cpu)])

    model = PPO2(MlpPolicy, env, verbose=1)
    model.learn(total_timesteps=25000)

    obs = env.reset()
    for _ in range(1000):
        action, _states = model.predict(obs)
        obs, rewards, dones, info = env.step(action)
        env.render()
```

items.title: ** ARCHIVE FAILED ** Exit status: 65 at the very last step of the archive process
items.body:
I am running gym using fastlane and I have my lane gym method as follows:

```
gym(
	scheme: "App Name", #Contains a space 
	configuration: "Beta",
	clean: true,
	include_bitcode: false,
	export_method: "enterprise",
	export_options: {
	provisioningProfiles: { 
	        <APP_BUNDLE_ID> => "match InHouse bundle id",
	        <RICH_PUSH_BUNDLE_ID> => "match InHouse rich push bundle ID"
	      	}
    	},
	output_directory: $OUTPUT_PATH,
	skip_profile_detection: true
)
```

I get hit by a failure while trying to ```touch app name.app```. When I try to locate this folder `InstallationBuildProductsLocation` I can't seem to find it. 
I tried to archive with Xcode and it works 100% of the time. Tried to delete my provisioning profiles and redownloading them, and still nothing.

items.title: Source Code of the Gym Webiste
items.body:
Hi,

I was wondering if the OpenAI team would consider releasing the source code of https://gym.openai.com. Recently I have been struggling to record a video of the agent's performances in `Taxi-v3` because the video recording wrapper produces this JSON file (https://gym.openai.com/videos/2019-10-21--mqt8Qj1mwo/Taxi-v3/original.json) that is not directly playable. Upon further inspection, it appears that OpenAI actually customized a version of asciinema to do so. 

If for various reasons it is not desirable for the team to open the source of the gym website, could you maybe consider releasing the source code of the customized version of asciinema? Or perhaps someone could write some instructions about how to play the JSON file as a video?

Thanks a lot.
